description: {"blocks":[{"key":"3luk8","text":"Using the registration transformations calculated in low-resolution (as described CODA (part 2): calculate registration on low-resolution tissue images), register the nuclear coordinates generated in CODA (part 5): nuclear coordinate generation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4v4ib","text":"As input, this function needs the path to the low-resolution images that were registered in CODA-part2 (pth1x), the path containing the coordinates calculated in CODA-part4 (pthcoords), and the scale factor between these images. For cell detection performed in 10x and registration calculated in 1x, ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":92,"length":10},{"key":1,"offset":162,"length":10}],"data":{}},{"key":"7q2vk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edsle","text":"scale=10;","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fc5gj","text":"register_cell_coordinates(pth1x,pthcoords,scale);","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":49}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ei0j2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ag8c","text":"*if the yellow dots do not line up over the tissue, there is a problem in your code.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"36FD7EAC46254531BA3FA9BF30FF1865","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.kxygxym3dl8j/v1"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8C0393124F5B45C5A0659C8CF847F976","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.yxmvme7eog3p/v1"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6n6u6","text":"This function will create a subfolder inside pthcoords named ‘cell_coordinates_registered.’ Inside that subfolder will be a mat file corresponding to each tif image. Inside each mat file will be a variable named ‘xy’ (unregistered cell coordinates), ‘xyg’ (globally registered cell coordinates), and ‘xye’ (elastically registered cell coordinates), all saved at the same low-resolution as the original registration images used in CODA-part2.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":430,"length":10}],"data":{}},{"key":"1k96l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dj8l5","text":"pthcoordsE=[pthcoords,'cell_coordinates_registered'];","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":53}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"36FD7EAC46254531BA3FA9BF30FF1865","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.kxygxym3dl8j/v1"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"59glb","text":"Next, create volcell, a matrix containing the nuclear labels in a volumetric matrix the same size and resolution of the tissue matrix constructed in CODA-part4. To call this function, you need to define the folder containing the registered, classified images created in CODA-part4, the folder containing the registered cell coordinates, the folder containing the tissue matrix created in CODA-part4, and the scale between the high-resolution, classified images and the high-resolution images used for cell detection (this is probably 1).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":13,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":149,"length":10},{"key":1,"offset":270,"length":10},{"key":2,"offset":388,"length":10}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8C0393124F5B45C5A0659C8CF847F976","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.yxmvme7eog3p/v1"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8C0393124F5B45C5A0659C8CF847F976","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.yxmvme7eog3p/v1"}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8C0393124F5B45C5A0659C8CF847F976","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.yxmvme7eog3p/v1"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1ceop","text":"Define the folders containing the registered, classified images, the registered nuclear coordinates, and the tissue volume matrix:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8uv4t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edkg8","text":"pthclassifiedE=[pthclassified,'registeredE'];","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":45}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eov25","text":"pthcoordsE=[pthcoords,'cell_coordinates_registered'];","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":53}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1tl1p","text":"pthvolume=[pth,'lung_data'];","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"blod9","text":"Next, define the scale between the high-resolution images used for tissue classification in CODA-part3 and the high-resolution images used for cell detection in CODA-part5. If the classification and cell detection were applied to the same resolution images (this is likely), the scale is 1. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":92,"length":10},{"key":1,"offset":161,"length":10}],"data":{}},{"key":"3sfm2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ajclv","text":"scale=1;","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"40B186B3701F428B911D730B7B96C289","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.81wgbz1x3gpk/v1"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"DB7E9F7512EC4467A7837DF26C15939C","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.dm6gpz8z8lzp/v1"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"89aq4","text":"Beyond the scope of this guide, consider volshow or patch","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":41,"length":8},{"style":"bold","offset":52,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"74gh0","text":"Now, call the make_volcell function:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1tg73","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ksmb","text":"build_cell_volume(pthclassifiedE,pthcoordsE,pthvolume,scale,nwhite)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":67}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ftv6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2rf3e","text":"This function will create a 3D matrix containing nuclear coordinates. The matrix will be at the same resolution as the tissue volume matrix, and automatically crop out the same background space that was manually selected for removal in CODA-part4. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":236,"length":10}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8C0393124F5B45C5A0659C8CF847F976","url":"http://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.yxmvme7eog3p/v1"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d5ea","text":"Primarily beyond the scope of this guide, as most spatial calculations must are custom to the biological question. Some basic considerations are in the following sections","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dckc7","text":"To quantify cellularity.  number of cells in class 2 (use vol or your smoothed volS):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":24},{"style":"bold","offset":58,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":79,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"crh6d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ec4vl","text":"tmp=double(volcell).*double(vol==2);","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":36}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3nmog","text":"cell_type_2=sum(tmp(:));","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1sdms","text":"For more complex quantifications:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bmt6t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"20sek","text":"Consider the functions bwdist, regionprops3, and custom functions you create. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":23,"length":6},{"style":"bold","offset":31,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d1jpo","text":"Finally, nwhite is the whitespace class from the deep learning model. Here, let’s again use nwhite=6 (the background class number from the sample lung model.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f52bm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jnf2","text":"nwhite=6;","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1snpv","text":"To validate that the function creates a variable volcell that is the same resolution and crop as the tissue matrix vol, the function will display two images. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":49,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":115,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ejqvs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"159ub","text":"1. the function will display an overlay of the center image from vol and volcell.\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":73,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9qj2e","text":"2. the function will display an overlay of the z-projections of vol and volcell.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":64,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":72,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"68psf","text":"\nIf either of these images do not appear overlayed (you see two separate, unaligned tissues), there was a problem with the construction of either vol or volcell.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":146,"length":4},{"style":"bold","offset":153,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
